1.1:
How lonely sits the city
    that was full of people!
How she has become like a widow,
    who was once great among the nations!
She who was a princess among the provinces
    has become a slave!
1.4:
The roads to Zion mourn
    because no one comes to the solemn feasts.
All her gates are desolate;
    her priests sigh,
her virgins are afflicted,
    and she herself suffers bitterly.
1.5:
Her adversaries have become her masters,
    her enemies prosper;
for the Lord has afflicted her
    because of the multitude of her transgressions.
Her children have gone into captivity
    before the enemy.
1.6:
From the daughter of Zion
    all her beauty has departed.
Her princes have become like deer
    that find no pasture;
they fled without strength
    before the pursuer.
1.7:
In the days of her affliction and misery
    Jerusalem remembers all her pleasant things
    that she had in the days of old.
When her people fell into the hand of the enemy,
    there was no one to help her.
The adversaries saw her
    and mocked at her desolation.
1.10:
The adversary has spread his hand
    over all her precious things;
for she has seen the nations
    enter her sanctuary,
those whom You commanded
    not to enter Your congregation.
1.11:
All her people groan,
    as they search for bread;
they trade their treasures for food
    to restore their strength.
Look, O Lord, and consider,
    for I am despised.
1.12:
Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by?
    Look and see
if there is any sorrow like my sorrow,
    which was brought upon me,
which the Lord has inflicted
    on the day of His fierce anger.
1.14:
The yoke of my transgressions
    was bound; by His hand
they were fastened together; they were set upon my neck.
    He made my strength fail;
the Lord delivered me into the hands
    of those whom I am not able to withstand.
1.18:
The Lord is in the right,
    for I have rebelled against His commandment.
Hear now, all peoples,
    and see my sorrow;
my virgins and my young men
    have gone into captivity.
1.19:
I called for my lovers,
    but they deceived me;
my priests and my elders
    perished in the city,
while they sought food
    to restore their strength.
1.21:
They have heard my groaning,
    yet there is no one to comfort me.
All my enemies have heard of my trouble;
    they are glad that You have done it.
Bring the day that You have announced,
    that they become like me.

2.1:
How the Lord has covered the daughter of Zion
    with a cloud in His anger!
He has cast down from heaven to the earth
    the beauty of Israel;
He has not remembered His footstool
    in the day of His anger.
2.3:
He has cut off in fierce anger
    all the might of Israel;
He has drawn back His right hand
    from before the enemy.
He has burned against Jacob
    like a flaming fire, devouring all around.
2.7:
The Lord has scorned His altar,
    He has disowned His sanctuary;
He has given up the walls of her palaces
    into the hand of the enemy.
They have made a noise in the house of the Lord
    as on the day of a solemn feast.
2.10:
The elders of the daughter of Zion
    sit on the ground in silence;
they throw dust on their heads
    and gird themselves with sackcloth.
The virgins of Jerusalem
    bow their heads to the ground.
2.11:
My eyes fail with tears,
    my spirit is greatly troubled;
my bile is poured on the ground
    because of the destruction of the daughter of my people,
because the children and infants faint
    in the streets of the city.
2.12:
They say to their mothers,
    “Where is grain and wine?”
when they faint like a wounded man
    in the streets of the city,
as their life is poured out
    on their mothers’ bosom.
2.13:
What can I say for you,
    to what shall I liken you,
    O daughter of Jerusalem?
What shall I compare with you,
    that I may comfort you,
    O virgin daughter of Zion?
For your devastation is great like the sea;
    who can heal you?
2.14:
Your prophets have seen for you
    false and deceptive visions;
they have not revealed your iniquity,
    to bring back your captives,
but have seen for you oracles
    that are false and misleading.
2.15:
All who pass by
    clap their hands at you;
they hiss and shake their heads
    at the daughter of Jerusalem, saying,
“Is this the city that men call
    the perfection of beauty,
    the joy of the whole earth?”
2.18:
Their heart cried to the Lord:
O wall of the daughter of Zion,
    let your tears run down
    like a river day and night;
give yourself no rest,
    your eyes no respite!
2.19:
Arise, cry out in the night,
    at the beginning of the watches;
pour out your heart like water
    before the face of the Lord.
Lift your hands to Him
    for the lives of your young children,
who faint for hunger
    at the head of every street.
2.20:
Look, O Lord, and consider!
    To whom have You done this?
Should the women eat their offspring,
    the children who were born healthy?
Should the priest and the prophet be killed
    in the sanctuary of the Lord?

3.1:
I am the man who has seen affliction
    by the rod of His wrath.
3.2:
He has driven and brought me
    into darkness without any light.
3.3:
Surely against me has He turned His hand
    continually, the whole day long.
3.4:
My flesh and my skin He has made waste away;
    He has broken my bones;
3.5:
He has besieged and enveloped me
    with gall and travail.
3.6:
He has set me in dark places,
    like the dead of long ago.
3.7:
He has hedged me in so that I cannot get out;
    He has made my chain heavy.
3.8:
Even when I cry for help,
    He shuts out my prayer.
3.9:
He has blocked my ways with hewn stone;
    He has made my paths crooked.
3.10:
He is to me a bear lying in wait,
    a lion in hiding.
3.11:
He has turned aside my ways and torn me in pieces;
    He has made me desolate.
3.12:
He has bent His bow
    and set me as a target for the arrow.
3.13:
He has caused the arrows of His quiver
    to pierce my inward parts.
3.14:
I have become the derision of all my people,
    their mocking song all the day.
3.15:
He has filled me with bitterness,
    He has sated me with wormwood.
3.16:
He has made my teeth grind on gravel,
    and covered me with ashes.
3.17:
My soul is bereft of peace;
    I have forgotten prosperity.
3.18:
So I say, “My strength and my hope
    from the Lord have perished.”
3.19:
Remember my affliction and my misery,
    the wormwood and the gall.
3.20:
Surely my soul remembers
    and is humbled within me.
3.21:
But this I call to mind,
    and therefore I have hope:
3.22:
It is of the Lord’s mercies that we are not consumed;
    His compassions do not fail.
3.23:
They are new every morning;
    great is Your faithfulness.
3.24:
“The Lord is my portion,” says my soul,
    “therefore I will hope in Him.”
3.25:
The Lord is good to those who wait for Him,
    to the soul who seeks Him.
3.26:
It is good that a man should wait quietly
    for the salvation of the Lord.
3.27:
It is good for a man to bear the yoke
    in his youth.
3.28:
Let him sit alone in silence
    when it is laid on him;
3.29:
let him put his mouth in the dust—
    there may yet be hope.
3.30:
Let him give his cheek to the one who strikes,
    and let him be filled with insults.
3.31:
For the Lord
    will not cast off forever.
3.32:
But though He causes grief, yet He will have compassion
    according to the abundance of His mercies.
3.33:
For He does not afflict from His heart,
    nor grieve the sons of men.
3.34:
To crush underfoot
    all the prisoners of the earth,
3.35:
to turn aside the justice due a man
    in the presence of the Most High,
3.36:
to subvert a man in his cause,
    the Lord does not approve.
3.37:
Who is he who speaks and it comes to pass,
    unless the Lord has commanded it?
3.38:
Is it not from the mouth of the Most High
    that good and bad proceed?
3.39:
Why should a living man complain,
    a man for the punishment of his sins?
3.40:
Let us search and try our ways,
    and return to the Lord!
3.41:
Let us lift up our hearts and hands
    to God in heaven:
3.42:
We have transgressed and rebelled;
    You have not pardoned.
3.43:
You have covered Yourself with anger and pursued us;
    You have killed and not pitied.
3.44:
You have covered Yourself with a cloud,
    so that no prayer should pass through.
3.45:
You have made us filthy refuse
    in the midst of the peoples.
3.46:
All our enemies have opened their mouths
    against us.
3.47:
Panic and snare have come upon us,
    desolation and destruction.
3.48:
My eyes flow with rivers of tears
    for the destruction of the daughter of my people.
3.49:
My eyes flow and do not cease,
    without respite,
3.50:
until the Lord from heaven
    looks down and sees.
3.51:
My eyes bring suffering to my soul
    at the fate of all the daughters of my city.
3.52:
My enemies chased me like a bird,
    without cause.
3.53:
They cut off my life in the pit
    and cast stones on me.
3.54:
Waters flowed over my head;
    I said, “I am cut off!”
3.55:
I called on Your name, O Lord,
    from the lowest pit.
3.56:
You have heard my plea:
    “Do not close Your ear to my cry for help!”
3.57:
You drew near on the day I called on You,
    and You said, “Do not fear!”
3.58:
O Lord, You have pleaded the case for my soul;
    You have redeemed my life.
3.59:
O Lord, You have seen the wrong done to me;
    judge my case.
3.60:
You have seen all their vengeance,
    all their schemes against me.
3.61:
You have heard their reproach, O Lord,
    all their schemes against me,
3.62:
the lips of my enemies and
    their devices against me all the day.
3.63:
Look at their sitting down and their rising up;
    I am their mocking song.
3.64:
Render to them a recompense, O Lord,
    according to the work of their hands.
3.65:
Give them hardness of heart;
    may Your curse be upon them!
3.66:
In Your anger pursue and destroy them
    from under Your heavens, O Lord!

4.1:
How the gold has become dim!
    How the most fine gold has changed!
The stones of the sanctuary lie scattered
    at the head of every street.
4.2:
The precious sons of Zion,
    comparable to fine gold,
how they are esteemed as earthen pots,
    the work of a potter’s hands!
4.3:
Even the jackals offer the breast;
    they nurse their young,
yet the daughter of my people has become cruel,
    like ostriches in the wilderness.
4.4:
The tongue of the infant cleaves
    to the roof of his mouth for thirst;
the children beg for bread,
    but no one divides it for them.
4.5:
Those who once ate delicacies
    are desolate in the streets;
those who were brought up in scarlet
    embrace ash heaps.
4.6:
For the iniquity of the daughter of my people
    is greater than the sin of Sodom,
which was overthrown in a moment,
    and no hands were wrung for her.
4.7:
Her princes were purer than snow,
    whiter than milk;
their bodies were more ruddy than rubies,
    their appearance like sapphire.
4.9:
Those killed by the sword
    are better off than those who die of hunger,
for they pine away,
    stricken for want of the fruits of the field.
4.10:
The hands of compassionate women
    have boiled their own children;
they became their food in the destruction
    of the daughter of my people.
4.11:
The Lord has fulfilled His fury,
    He has poured out His fierce anger.
He kindled a fire in Zion,
    and it has devoured its foundations.
4.12:
The kings of the earth, and all the inhabitants of the world,
    would not have believed
that the adversary and the enemy could enter
    the gates of Jerusalem.
4.13:
This was for the sins of her prophets
    and the iniquities of her priests,
who poured out in her midst the blood of the righteous.
4.14:
They wandered,
    blind, in the streets;
they have defiled themselves with blood,
    so that no one could touch their garments.
4.15:
They cried out to them, “Depart! Unclean!
    Depart, depart, do not touch us!”
Therefore they fled and wandered;
    men among the nations said,
    “They shall live with us no longer.”
4.17:
Our eyes failed us,
    watching vainly for help;
in our watchtowers we watched
    for a nation that could not save us.
4.18:
They tracked our steps
    so that we could not walk in our streets.
Our end drew near; our days were numbered,
    for our end had come.
4.19:
Our pursuers were swifter
    than the eagles of the skies.
They pursued us on the mountains;
    they lay in wait for us in the wilderness.
4.20:
The breath of our life, the anointed king of the Lord,
    was captured in their traps,
of whom we said, “Under his shadow
    we shall live among the nations.”
4.21:
Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom,
    you who dwell in the land of Uz!
The cup shall also pass to you;
    you shall become drunk and strip yourself bare.

5.1:
Remember, O Lord, what has come upon us;
    look, and see our reproach!
5.2:
Our inheritance has been turned over to strangers,
    our homes to foreigners.
5.3:
We have become orphans and fatherless;
    our mothers are like widows.
5.4:
We must pay for the water we drink;
    our wood is sold to us.
5.5:
Our pursuers are at our necks;
    we labor and have no rest.
5.6:
We have given our hand to Egypt and to Assyria,
    to be satisfied with bread.
5.7:
Our fathers sinned and are no more,
    but we bear their iniquities.
5.8:
Slaves rule over us;
    there is no one to deliver us from their hand.
5.9:
We get our bread at the peril of our lives,
    because of the sword in the wilderness.
5.10:
Our skin is hot as an oven,
    because of the terrible famine.
5.11:
They ravished the women in Zion,
    the virgins in the cities of Judah.
5.12:
Princes were hung up by their hands,
    the faces of elders were not honored.
5.13:
Young men ground at the millstones;
    boys staggered under loads of wood.
5.14:
The elders have left the city gate,
    the young men stopped their music.
5.15:
The joy of our hearts has ceased;
    our dancing has turned into mourning.
5.16:
The crown has fallen from our head;
    woe to us, for we have sinned!
5.17:
For this our heart is faint;
    for these things our eyes grow dim;
5.18:
because of Mount Zion, which is desolate,
    with foxes walking upon it.
5.19:
You, O Lord, remain forever;
    Your throne endures from generation to generation.
5.20:
Why do You forget us forever,
    and forsake us for so long a time?
5.21:
Restore us to Yourself, O Lord, that we may return!
    Renew our days as of old,
5.22:
unless You have utterly rejected us,
    and are very angry with us.
